Dr. David G. Danskin, Associate Professor in Education
and head of the Student Counseling Service, will resign his duties
at Hopkins next month to assume positions on the staff of
Kansas State College in Manhattan, Kansas.
Dr. Da,nskin's duties will be
enlarged over those he held here
when he becomes associate professor of psychology and associate director of the Student
Psychology Clinic at the college.
He expects to vacate his Hopkins
positions around February 15.
Reasons for Leaving
In explaining his reasons for
leaving, Dr. Danskin termed his
new position "a better one for
my particular interests." He
pointed out that his duties in the
Psychology Department at Kansas State and the assistant
directorship of a "fairly large
counseling clinic" are "more in
keeping with my own background."
Dr. Danskin will also teach
courses in graduate psychology
and will do research in institutional and basic psychology at
the college.
Boston Native
A native of Boston, Dr. Danskin was raised in California,
where in 1950 he graduated,
magna cum laude with an A.B.
degree in psychology at the University of Redlands. He received
both his Masters and Ph.D. de-

grees in psychology at Ohio State
University, the latter coming in
1954. Since then he has been
a member of the faculty at Johns
Hopkins University, where in
addition to his positions as associate professor af -education
and head of the Student Psychology Clinic he has taught courses
in counseling and testing guidance, and this term is serving as
secretary of
the Freshman
Academic Standing Committee.

IFB Representation
At the beginning of this school year, the Inter-Fraternity Board overwhelmingly rejected a proposal that
the then-present representatives be replaced on the Board
by the president of each fraternity. •
The motion had been supported by both Dr. William
Morrill and Dr. G. Wilson Shaffer. A News-Letter editorial of October 3 had also supported the plan.
But it was rejected with only one vote cast in its
favor. There were two arguments: (1) It's too near
rushing, and (2) the Board is doing a competent job.
It has now been over two months since rushing ended
and the motion has still not been re-considered. Moreover, the Board has, in several instances, shown evidences
of its weaknesses. It is not doing a competent job.
The manner in which the IFB has handled the application of Zeta Beta Tau, the seething mass of rushing
violations, the absence of officers from IFB meetings and
the lateness with which fraternity grades were turned in
to the Registrar are examples.
We feel that these cases are not unusual but clear
indications that something is. lacking in the makeup of
the Board. Many fraternity members, moreover, feel
that the prestige and effectiveness of the Board, while
Dot completely gone, has deteriorated.
Too often, the position of IFB delegate is considered
too lightly by fraternities. A man may often be assigned
to this job only because it is felt any job will boost his
morale and help him generally.
We submit that one way to raise the effectiveness
and prestige would be to seat the president of each fraternity as the delegate to the Board. By making the
president the representative, men of greater ability would
sit, and would thereby give the decisions of the Board

At the beginning of this school year, the Inter-Fraternity Board overwhelmingly rejected a proposal that
the then-present representatives be replaced on the Board
by the president of each fraternity. •
The motion had been supported by both Dr. William

But it was rejected with only one vote cast in its
favor. There were two arguments: (1) It's too near
rushing, and (2) the Board is doing a competent job.
It has now been over two months since rushing ended
and the motion has still not been re-considered. Moreover, the Board has, in several instances, shown evidences
of its weaknesses. It is not doing a competent job.
The manner in which the IFB has handled the application of Zeta Beta Tau, the seething mass of rushing
violations, the absence of officers from IFB meetings and
the lateness with which fraternity grades were turned in
to the Registrar are examples.
We feel that these cases are not unusual but clear
indications that something is. lacking in the makeup of
the Board. Many fraternity members, moreover, feel
that the prestige and effectiveness of the Board, while
Dot completely gone, has deteriorated.
Too often, the position of IFB delegate is considered
too lightly by fraternities. A man may often be assigned
to this job only because it is felt any job will boost his
morale and help him generally.
We submit that one way to raise the effectiveness
and prestige would be to seat the president of each fraternity as the delegate to the Board. By making the
president the representative, men of greater ability would
sit, and would thereby give the decisions of the Board
greater weight and insure their more careful consideration by the community as a whole.
Several fraternities already seem to realize this.
Five fraternities are now represented on the IFB by
their presidents. We hope that other fraternities will
come to realize the worthiness of this proposal and enact
